climbs.name: Sunny Butterflies
climbs.fa: Clark Alexis, Tom Jüngst and Tom Kalakay 1984

content.description:
An interesting and somewhat serious route with ground fall potential. It is more of a highball boulder problem, then a short 5.8 trad climb, separated by a ledge.

Climb diagonally left up a somewhat slopey rail to the single bolt. Move up into underclings then climb to the ledge on good edges. Aside from the lone bolt there are few, if any, options to protect this lower section. A fall on the last moves would result in cratering from 25-30 feet up, but the holds are good. After gaining the ledge, plug a small cam behind a flake, mantle the flake, then move into the corner/roof and climb the crack to the top. Belay on the large ledge. Either walk off right, or continue to the other routes above.
content.protection: 1 bolt, a small cam for the ledge (yellow TCU), a few hand sized pieces for the upper corner and crack. A horizontal takes small to medium cams and nuts for the anchor.
content.location: Just left of the access gully for the pillar, look for the single bolt and roof crack

content.description:
P1 5.7 Start in the obvious corner and climb up to the black patch of rock and belay from bolted anchor.

P2 5.7 Follow the crack/corner up and left to bolted anchor near a small tree on a big ledge.

P3 5.9 From the ledge head left to the corner, climb up and over the roof (fun move/crux) to easier ground and the top of the cliff. Belay from near the tree at the top of the crag.
content.location:
The route starts about 20 yards from the parking area.

Walk off to the east down the sloping ramps.

content.description: Crux is definitely the first 10 feet off the second big ledge. gear is very sparse and requires some know-how to place. You can get some nuts in, and the moves are tenuous. Definitely gets your heart pumping, and is probably the most asthetic line up neat rock due to how direct it is. Do it in 2 pitches, as there is no good place to build an anchor after the first ledge.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches, small nuts for the last pitch
content.location: Go straight up the "v groove" open book looking part of neat rock.

climbs.name: Rock Lobster
climbs.fa: Tom Kalakay, Mark Fontaine, Tom Jüngst 13 Feb 84

content.description:
A fun, steep route on great rock.

From the second pitch belay of the Standard Route, climb up weaknesses to the fixed pin below the left leaning crack.  Take care on the start of this route!

Follow the left leaning crack to the upper corner.  Follow the final right facing corner to the top.

Thin and sustained with a spicy start.  Nice for a sunny, cold winter day when the fish aren't biting and the rattlesnakes are hibernating.
content.protection: Standard rack to include a few small to hand sized cams and a few nuts.
content.location:
Follow the standard "Birdshit Express" for two pitches.

Walk off to the right down the exposed east facing ramps.

Watch for rattlesnakes.

content.description: Also known as the Spire, Chicken head, Marmot's head, etc.  Multiple variations can be done depending on where you set the rope.  Choose one of the various easy 5.6 or so cracks until you get just under neath the obvious roof, traverse around right.  Then pull through a few bulges near the top before traversing left to top out at the anchor.  Walk off right, or use the rap rings on the left side of the formation.
content.protection: Three bolts are on top for top roping.  The two west facing bolts have chains and rap rings.  Use a cordlette to set up a rope on the south face.
content.location: As you pull up to the the main parking area of Neat Rock its right at the base in the center of the crag.  Scramble up the left gully then squeeze through a hole to get to the anchor or head East and hike the main walk off trail used by many other routes.

content.description: Easy scramble up boulders until you get to the last 25 feet or so. There are only a couple moves of 5.10 with a solid two finger jam/wedge mixed in there. Fun, quick route if you don't have much time left in the day, but just want one more.
content.protection: There are three randomly placed bolts at the top to build a toprope and two that have chains to rap from.
content.location: About 20 yards lookers right of the Standard Route. Pretty recognizable overhang.
